channel.title: Java - Printing the result of a value chosen from an array in a different class?

item.title: Java - Printing the result of a value chosen from an array in a different class?
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:31, topic:378924”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=474783.msg3476995#msg3476995 date=1295781436]
List specialDrops = Arrays.asList(new Integer[] {4151, 995});

Would probably be better, but I was just working with the information he already had given me.
[/quote]
If “better” means worse then yes. You’re creating a pointless List, a pointless Integer array which is like a million bytes big and a pointless process to convert it all.

Yes, a HashSet would probably be the fastest but since it’s an small array that’s not going to hold any more than 30 elements you might aswell just do a linear search on it. It would be just as fast as any other search method on an array.[/quote]Yes, better means worse in this case, which is why I didn’t suggest it in the first place etc

Read full topic
item.source: Java - Printing the result of a value chosen from an array in a different class?

item.title: Java - Printing the result of a value chosen from an array in a different class?
item.dc:creator: @iKilem iKilem
item.description:
@iKilem wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:30, topic:378924”][quote author=iKilem link=topic=474783.msg3476991#msg3476991 date=1295780959]

I’m not ignoring anything that you’re saying, I’m saying any time you may possibly save (which would be extremely minimal) would probably be counter balanced on initialization of the variable anyway (also because you’d still need to make the array a collection to set the hashset)

You were arguing about using an (Array)List. I’m saying a better solution is to use a HashSet. Even if the benefits are insignificant in this case, it’s still good practice. It wouldn’t be counter-balanced, considering you only need to initialise once. Your way of invoking Arrays.asList() to return a List could easily be avoided if you simply declare specialDrops as a List.
[/quote]List specialDrops = Arrays.asList(new Integer[] {4151, 995});

Would probably be better, but I was just working with the information he already had given me.[/quote]
Just trivial stuff, but the method asList() accepts varargs, meaning you could do asList(4151, 995). Also, it makes more sense to declare it as a Collection. Like I said earlier, something like this is not what I would call “cleaner”. Less lines is all it is. The point of an ArrayList is that it’s dynamic. I would rather use a plain array.

Just to throw this out in case people missed it:

iKilem:

If you want something efficient, perhaps use a HashMap i[/i], but it may turn out to be worse if the collection isn’t that big.

Read full topic

Would probably be better, but I was just working with the information he already had given me.[/quote]
If “better” means worse then yes. You’re creating a pointless List, a pointless Integer array which is like a million bytes big and a pointless process to convert it all.

Yes, a HashSet would probably be the fastest but since it’s an small array that’s not going to hold any more than 30 elements you might aswell just do a linear search on it. It would be just as fast as any other search method on an array.

[quote=“iKilem, post:29, topic:378924”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=474783.msg3476965#msg3476965 date=1295777501]
I’m not ignoring anything that you’re saying, I’m saying any time you may possibly save (which would be extremely minimal) would probably be counter balanced on initialization of the variable anyway (also because you’d still need to make the array a collection to set the hashset)
[/quote]
You were arguing about using an (Array)List. I’m saying a better solution is to use a HashSet. Even if the benefits are insignificant in this case, it’s still good practice. It wouldn’t be counter-balanced, considering you only need to initialise once. Your way of invoking Arrays.asList() to return a List could easily be avoided if you simply declare specialDrops as a List.[/quote]List specialDrops = Arrays.asList(new Integer[] {4151, 995});

Would probably be better, but I was just working with the information he already had given me.

item.title: Java - Printing the result of a value chosen from an array in a different class?
item.dc:creator: @iKilem iKilem
item.description:
@iKilem wrote:

Davidi2:

I’m not ignoring anything that you’re saying, I’m saying any time you may possibly save (which would be extremely minimal) would probably be counter balanced on initialization of the variable anyway (also because you’d still need to make the array a collection to set the hashset)

You were arguing about using an (Array)List. I’m saying a better solution is to use a HashSet. Even if the benefits are insignificant in this case, it’s still good practice. It wouldn’t be counter-balanced, considering you only need to initialise once. Your way of invoking Arrays.asList() to return a List could easily be avoided if you simply declare specialDrops as a List.

item.title: Java - Printing the result of a value chosen from an array in a different class?
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“iKilem, post:27, topic:378924”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=474783.msg3476450#msg3476450 date=1295738020]

Why should he use a hashmap?

Sorry, I meant HashSet (kinda forgot that we were dealing with item ids). The time complexity for its contains() method is O(1). Should be faster than having to potentially go through all the item ids (which is what you would do with a plain array or an ArrayList).
[/quote]You’d do the exact same thing as you would with a List…

sigh Why are you ignoring what I’m saying? Is it because you don’t understand? In that case, just don’t comment…[/quote]I’m not ignoring anything that you’re saying, I’m saying any time you may possibly save (which would be extremely minimal) would probably be counter balanced on initialization of the variable anyway (also because you’d still need to make the array a collection to set the hashset)

item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

[quote=“Dinoboy, post:25, topic:378924”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=474783.msg3476450#msg3476450 date=1295738020]

Why should he use a hashmap?

Sorry, I meant HashSet (kinda forgot that we were dealing with item ids). The time complexity for its contains() method is O(1). Should be faster than having to potentially go throuHashSetgh all the item ids (which is what you would do with a plain array or an ArrayList).
[/quote]You’d do the exact same thing as you would with a List…

like he said, speed is O(1)

it’s not same, arrays contain() method has a speed of O(n)

also, technically a HashSet is a HashMap since it encapsulates over a HashMap :P[/quote]

It’s called complexity, not speed.

item.title: Java - Printing the result of a value chosen from an array in a different class?
item.dc:creator: @iKilem iKilem
item.description:
@iKilem wrote:

Davidi2:

Why should he use a hashmap?

Sorry, I meant HashSet (kinda forgot that we were dealing with item ids). The time complexity for its contains() method is O(1). Should be faster than having to potentially go through all the item ids (which is what you would do with a plain array or an ArrayList).

Read full topic
item.source: Java - Printing the result of a value chosen from an array in a different class?

item.title: Java - Printing the result of a value chosen from an array in a different class?
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“iKilem, post:21, topic:378924”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=474783.msg3476328#msg3476328 date=1295731199]

[quote author=Dinoboy link=topic=474783.msg3476326#msg3476326 date=1295731124]

@Chassy13 Don’t go with Davidi2’s suggestion. Simply looping through an array would be faster. If you want something efficient, perhaps use a HashMap, but it may turn out to be worse if the collection isn’t that big.
[/quote]Turning an array into a list and checking if it contains an object is fast and clean…

not really, it builds a list each time and then LOOPS over it to check if the value is contained.

it’s faster to just cut out the list building and loop by yourself
[/quote]He’s going to be checking a list of less than 100 values, I think in this case cleanliness is more important?
If my way doesn’t work, then he should use a loop. OR he could store the values as a list to start with.

Cleanliness?

for (int item : specialDrops) {
    if (itemDroppped == item) {
        PlayerHandler.messageToAll = "Username just got " + ItemHandler.getNameFromId(itemDropped) + " by killing the monster!";
    }
}

I wouldn’t call that messy. Also, like I said, OP should use a HashMap. It’s faster (depends) and “clean”. Dinoboy’s idea is also not bad.[/quote]Why should he use a hashmap?

Read full topic

item.title: Java - Printing the result of a value chosen from an array in a different class?
item.dc:creator: @iKilem iKilem
item.description:
@iKilem wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:19, topic:378924”][quote author=Dinoboy link=topic=474783.msg3476326#msg3476326 date=1295731124]

[quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=474783.msg3476320#msg3476320 date=1295730815]

@Chassy13 Don’t go with Davidi2’s suggestion. Simply looping through an array would be faster. If you want something efficient, perhaps use a HashMap, but it may turn out to be worse if the collection isn’t that big.
[/quote]Turning an array into a list and checking if it contains an object is fast and clean…

not really, it builds a list each time and then LOOPS over it to check if the value is contained.

it’s faster to just cut out the list building and loop by yourself
[/quote]He’s going to be checking a list of less than 100 values, I think in this case cleanliness is more important?
If my way doesn’t work, then he should use a loop. OR he could store the values as a list to start with.[/quote]
Cleanliness?

for (int item : specialDrops) {
    if (itemDroppped == item) {
        PlayerHandler.messageToAll = "Username just got " + ItemHandler.getNameFromId(itemDropped) + " by killing the monster!";
    }
}

I wouldn’t call that messy. Also, like I said, OP should use a HashMap. It’s faster (depends) and “clean”. Dinoboy’s idea is also not bad.

item.title: Java - Printing the result of a value chosen from an array in a different class?
item.dc:creator: @Dinoboy Dinoboy
item.description:
@Dinoboy wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:19, topic:378924”]He’s going to be checking a list of less than 100 values, I think in this case cleanliness is more important?
If my way doesn’t work, then he should use a loop. OR he could store the values as a list to start with.[/quote]

it’s not actually clean per-say. the code has just already been written and you just use one line to access it. you can do this:

public boolean contains(int[] array, int value) { for (int i = 0; i < array.length; i++) if (array[i] == value) return true; return false; }

then access it with one line too, however the latter doesn’t build and populate a new collection

item.dc:creator: @Dinoboy Dinoboy
item.description:
@Dinoboy wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:17, topic:378924”][quote author=iKilem link=topic=474783.msg3476203#msg3476203 date=1295724215]
@Chassy13 Don’t go with Davidi2’s suggestion. Simply looping through an array would be faster. If you want something efficient, perhaps use a HashMap, but it may turn out to be worse if the collection isn’t that big.
[/quote]Turning an array into a list and checking if it contains an object is fast and clean…[/quote]

not really, it builds a list each time and then LOOPS over it to check if the value is contained.

you could make it ‘one lined, clean, and fast’ by sorting the list then using Arrays.binarySearch

item.source: Java - Printing the result of a value chosen from an array in a different class?

item.title: Java - Printing the result of a value chosen from an array in a different class?
item.dc:creator: @Dinoboy Dinoboy
item.description:
@Dinoboy wrote:

iKilem:

Ah ok, but they don’t “go through the same exact process”. Like I said, a ternary statement is treated as a single sequence by the compiler. It is semantically different. Using a ternary expression can actually produce lengthier bytecode. For instance, if you want to increment a value. See: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2317614/java-bytecode-iconst-0-iadd-sequence. Point is that it pushes a constant and then adds. With a if-else statement, iinc would be used instead, since the compile treats it as two separate sequences.

yeah that’s true, in the case of incrementing it is different, i guess it varies on how you’re using them

Read full topic
item.source: Java - Printing the result of a value chosen from an array in a different class?

item.title: Java - Printing the result of a value chosen from an array in a different class?
item.dc:creator: @iKilem iKilem
item.description:
@iKilem wrote:

[quote=“Dinoboy, post:14, topic:378924”][quote author=iKilem link=topic=474783.msg3476180#msg3476180 date=1295723316]
My point is that it does make a difference, as you have just demonstrated. Your first claim was that the bytecode is the same. With the if-else statement, the astore instruction appears twice. With the ternary statement, you only see it after the compare block.
[/quote]

yeah i know that was your point i kept trying to edit my post to say you were right but my school internet is acting up, well it’s edited now.

they still go through the same exact process though, none is faster than the other (i still agree with you).

i guess the benefit of ternary is that it makes things shorter and also since it is one sequence this is possible:

obj.setValue(bool ? "yes" : "no");

Ah ok, but they don’t “go through the same exact process”. Like I said, a ternary statement is treated as a single sequence by the compiler. It is semantically different. Using a ternary expression can actually produce lengthier bytecode. For instance, if you want to increment a value. See: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2317614/java-bytecode-iconst-0-iadd-sequence. Point is that it pushes a constant and then adds. With a if-else statement, iinc would be used instead, since the compile treats it as two separate sequences.

@Chassy13 Don’t go with Davidi2’s suggestion. Simply looping through an array would be faster. If you want something efficient, perhaps use a HashMap, but it may turn out to be worse if the collection isn’t that big.

Read full topic
item.source: Java - Printing the result of a value chosen from an array in a different class?

item.title: Java - Printing the result of a value chosen from an array in a different class?
item.dc:creator: @Dinoboy Dinoboy
item.description:
@Dinoboy wrote:

iKilem:

My point is that it does make a difference, as you have just demonstrated. Your first claim was that the bytecode is the same. With the if-else statement, the astore instruction appears twice. With the ternary statement, you only see it after the compare block.

yeah i know that was your point i kept trying to edit my post to say you were right but my school internet is acting up, well it’s edited now.

they still go through the same exact process though, none is faster than the other (i still agree with you).

i guess the benefit of ternary is that it makes things shorter and also since it is one sequence this is possible:

obj.setValue(bool ? "yes" : "no");

item.source: Java - Printing the result of a value chosen from an array in a different class?

item.title: Java - Printing the result of a value chosen from an array in a different class?
item.dc:creator: @chassy13 Chassy13
item.description:
@chassy13 wrote:

I have to do this for seven NPCs, so would Davidi2’s method be the most efficient way to do this? I have different ways working but the amount of code that is required is ridiculous considering some NPCs will have 10-15 identified drops. I’ve send Davidi2 a PM about an error on his way, but if I need further help on it I will post in this thread again.

Thanks for help and information everyone.

Read full topic
item.source: Java - Printing the result of a value chosen from an array in a different class?

item.title: Java - Printing the result of a value chosen from an array in a different class?
item.dc:creator: @iKilem iKilem
item.description:
@iKilem wrote:

[quote=“Dinoboy, post:11, topic:378924”][quote author=iKilem link=topic=474783.msg3476087#msg3476087 date=1295718862]

well technically it IS restricted to two values, a ternary operation within a ternary operation is what it is.

i agree with the post above me, and it doesn’t particularly matter since it all compiles to the same bytecode. i guess it’s just preference (personally i never do ternary operations inside ternary operations, it is easier to read if you just do if-else)

Not necessarily. An if-else statement is two different sequences (the if and the else), while a ternary statement is a single sequence.
[/quote]

my point was it doesn’t really make a difference though:

public class Main {

	public static void main(String[] args) {
		boolean bool = false;
		String str = null;
		str = bool ? "x" : "t";
	}

}

bytecode:

0 iconst_0 1 istore_1 [bool] 2 aconst_null 3 astore_2 [str] 4 iload_1 [bool] 5 ifeq 13 8 ldc <String "x"> [16] 10 goto 15 13 ldc <String "t"> [18] 15 astore_2 [str] 16 return

public class Main {

	public static void main(String[] args) {
		boolean bool = false;
		String str = null;
		if (bool)
			str = "x";
		else
			str = "t";
	}

}

bytecode:

0 iconst_0 1 istore_1 [bool] 2 aconst_null 3 astore_2 [str] 4 iload_1 [bool] 5 ifeq 14 8 ldc <String "x"> [16] 10 astore_2 [str] 11 goto 17 14 ldc <String "t"> [18] 16 astore_2 [str] 17 return

one line difference and they do the same thing[/quote]
My point is that it does make a difference, as you have just demonstrated. Your first claim was that the bytecode is the same. With the if-else statement, the astore instruction appears twice. With the ternary statement, you only see it after the compare block.

Read full topic
item.source: Java - Printing the result of a value chosen from an array in a different class?

item.title: Java - Printing the result of a value chosen from an array in a different class?
item.dc:creator: @Dinoboy Dinoboy
item.description:
@Dinoboy wrote:

[quote=“iKilem, post:9, topic:378924”][quote author=Dinoboy link=topic=474783.msg3475970#msg3475970 date=1295712975]
well technically it IS restricted to two values, a ternary operation within a ternary operation is what it is.

i agree with the post above me, and it doesn’t particularly matter since it all compiles to the same bytecode. i guess it’s just preference (personally i never do ternary operations inside ternary operations, it is easier to read if you just do if-else)
[/quote]
Not necessarily. An if-else statement is two different sequences (the if and the else), while a ternary statement is a single sequence.[/quote]

my point was it doesn’t really make a difference though:

public class Main {

	public static void main(String[] args) {
		boolean bool = false;
		String str = null;
		str = bool ? "x" : "t";
	}

}

bytecode:

0 iconst_0 1 istore_1 [bool] 2 aconst_null 3 astore_2 [str] 4 iload_1 [bool] 5 ifeq 13 8 ldc <String "x"> [16] 10 goto 15 13 ldc <String "t"> [18] 15 astore_2 [str] 16 return

public class Main {

	public static void main(String[] args) {
		boolean bool = false;
		String str = null;
		if (bool)
			str = "x";
		else
			str = "t";
	}

}

bytecode:

0 iconst_0 1 istore_1 [bool] 2 aconst_null 3 astore_2 [str] 4 iload_1 [bool] 5 ifeq 14 8 ldc <String "x"> [16] 10 astore_2 [str] 11 goto 17 14 ldc <String "t"> [18] 16 astore_2 [str] 17 return

one line difference and they go through the same process but yeah ur right the bytecode isn’t EXACTLY the same

Read full topic

item.title: Java - Printing the result of a value chosen from an array in a different class?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Miss Silabsoft:

did you try Item2.NPC instead…

That’s right.

for(int z : Item2.NPC())

You are trying to call a function in class Item2 called NPC(), but there isn’t one is there? Only a field, so this will compile:

for(int z : Item2.NPC)

Got it?

As for what you are trying to do, of course you can print a value from an array.

Read full topic

i agree with the post above me, and it doesn’t particularly matter since it all compiles to the same bytecode. i guess it’s just preference (personally i never do ternary operations inside ternary operations, it is easier to read if you just do if-else)[/quote]
Not necessarily. An if-else statement is two different sequences (the if and the else), while a ternary statement is a single sequence.

item.source: Java - Printing the result of a value chosen from an array in a different class?
